page.title: 01THE CROSTON DISTRICT
page.content: The whole of the area is{flat and low- {lying, below 20m above sea level. Croston itself occupies the four grid squares in the extreme N.W. corner of the block and the only other built-up area is in the opposite S.E. corner square. Separating these two housing districts are the remaining 7sq.km. of farmland. The{R. Yarrow}skirts past Eccleston as it meanders on its way West to Croston. To the North of Croston the R.Lostock, a much smaller and more controlled stream,also flows E-W. Most of the land to the E. of Croston is fertile clay soil given over to {arable/pastoral farming}but to the W. and S. of Croston rich black mossland soil with arable farming predominates. The{road network}also centres on Croston and much through-traffic uses the A581, the B5249 and the B5247.
